Author and philosopher Alain de Botton has written about big thinkers, big ideas and about some of the giants of literature.
In his latest book, he reveals his own ambitions to think large, this time about design and architecture and what he calls an aesthetic revolution.
He describes why style, a beautiful house or exquisitely designed teacup, can bring such joy and why a gloomy hotel room can make us question the meaning of life.
In a collection of essays he challenges us to take a look at our surroundings to see how they shape us and how we shape them.
Does a home filled with dolls and teddy bears, he wonders, reflect a wish to escape from a harsh and cruel world?
Can a love of white, spare and minimal spaces be an attempt to fight a sense of chaos and disorder?
He questions the notion that aesthetic issues are shallow and argues that if we look a little deeper, our furniture, our houses, and our public buildings will speak to us in distinct personalities.
